en: Interview with Zachary James, student at the University of Tennessee Knoxville from Sevierville, Tennessee. James discusses his experience as a high school student in Sevierville during the time of the wildfires, including memories of classmates who were impacted, the closing of Sevier County schools, and the relief efforts. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Most of the people who lived in Gatlinburg were like, 'You should come down, see what happened, visit some of the areas that were affected.' Because a lot of these businesses depend on tourists."
Individuals (tourists or locals) not directly affected by the fire

Interview with Zachary James, student at the University of Tennessee Knoxville from Sevierville, Tennessee. James discusses his experience as a high school student in Sevierville during the time of the wildfires, including memories of classmates who were impacted, the closing of Sevier County schools, and the relief efforts. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Most of the people who lived in Gatlinburg were like, 'You should come down, see what happened, visit some of the areas that were affected.' Because a lot of these businesses depend on tourists."
Towns in East TN including Gatlinburg, Pigeon Forge, Sevierville and Pittman Center, TN

Could you state your name and where you're from?
Can you tell us how long you have lived in Sevierville and what it was like growing up there?
Growing up, did you spend a lot of time going to Gatlinburg?
Could you talk about the week leading up to the fire?
Were you and your friends concerned about the fire? Did that change when the wind started to pick up?
Was your family at any point preparing to evacuate?
You mentioned the news, was that how you were getting your information or were there other ways?
Once the power went out, how were getting updates?
When you started preparing to evacuate, what were you concerned with taking?
So your plan was to evacuate to family in South Carolina?
How did it feel the next couple days? Did it still feel like you might need to evacuate?
What was it like going back to school afterwards?
How did your teachers address the aftermath?
Was it something you and your friends talked about after?
How do you feel the fire has affected or shaped the community?
From a younger person's perspective, how do you feel social media played a role during and after the fire?
Have you and your family talked about provisions in case something like this happens again?
Is there anything else you would like to add?
Could you talk some more about the types of community support you saw?

seo.title: Interview with Zachary James, 2019-09-20 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
seo.description: Interview with Zachary James, student at the University of Tennessee Knoxville from Sevierville, Tennessee. James discusses his experience as a high school student in Sevierville during the time of the wildfires, including memories of classmates who were impacted, the closing of Sevier County schools, and the relief efforts. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Most of the people who lived in Gatlinburg were like, 'You should come down, see what happened, visit some of the areas that were affected.' Because a lot of these businesses depend on tourists."
